comments:
This course is an overview of several important aspects of modern biotechnology
from a chemical engineering perspective: DNA, enzymes and other biomolecules, cell
growth and metabolism, cellular and enzymatic reactors, bioseparation techniques,
molecular genetics, and biotransport processes.
Students for the most part found the material in this course as interesting, but
complained that the lectures were “boring” and “monotonous.” Most seniors said that the
material was redundant and very similar to what they learned in junior year. On the other
hand, non-seniors thought that the class was “a good introduction to biochemistry that
didn't require previous experience in biology.”
The students did not comment much on Professor Wattenbarger and instead
complained mostly about the course structure and its lack of depth. However, one student
said that the “professor is very nice, but seems to not have a mastery of the material at
times.”
Overall, students were upperclassmen. However, they recommended that it is
most suitable for non-seniors. The course load is large, but manageable, and the exams
are not extremely difficult.
